p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
Nearly million sheets botanic specimens require attention for progressive science work therefore filling vacancy
See M to T. Wilson, 5 August 1890. desirable particu[larly] as salary so small otherwise at all events additional youth needed
The file bears an annotation in an unknown hand: 'Promotion of French Jun?'

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
(Signature)
Baron von Mueller
On 14 November 1890 J. Mackenzie, Secretary, Public Service Board, wrote to T. Wilson, Under Secretary, Chief Secretary's Department: 'With reference to the vacant position of 3rd Herbarium Assistant in the office of the Government Botanist, I have the honour, by direction, to inform you that Mr W. C. D. Dewer, Junior Messenger in the Trade and Customs Department declines the appointment, and I am to ask whether you have any suggestion to offer in respect of such position. I am to invite your attention to Section 46 of Act No. 1133.' MS annotation in an unknown hand on 18 November: 'No action necessary says Mr Reddin as the Board are nominating a person to fill this vacancy' (Q90/11948, unit 560, VPRS 3992/P, PROV).
